binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Tunisian woman's head-veil, often square, worn over the head.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Term used to describe a watch movement which could be purchased from a supplier in various states of completion ranging from simple plates, pillars and balance-cock etc to a completely finished watch movement. Generally the ebauches were supplied with unfinished pivots and without any components of the escapement. Ebauches were purchased by "watchmakers" to be finished by skilled watchmakers ready for dialling and casing up for retail.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The names of the constituents should be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Adinkra are the textiles made by the Ashanti people of Ghana.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to indigo resist-dyed cloths made by the Yoruba people of Nigeria. Adire (translated as 'tie and dye') originally referred to simple indigo tie-dyed textiles on hand-woven cloth. The name is now applied more generally to refer to indigo-dyed cloth produced by the Yoruba people using a variety of resist-dyed techniques which evolved during the 20th century with the increase in imported cotton shirting. These cloths use starch resist-dyed techniques such as hand-painting (known as adire eleko) and stencilling, as well as stitch resist-dyed, tie-dyed and fold resist-dyed techniques. Some of these techniques may be used in combination on a single cloth.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Applied or inserted relief adornment to a variety of object types, most often vessels and figures. Also add the object type when using if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is added as an additional Object Name to records for objects which arwe used for advertising purposes, e.g. tokens, coins, posters, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, the term refers to a ritual fitting, usually Hathor-headed or female-headed, held in the hand. For the Department of Greece and Rome, it refers to a Gorgon's head worn on the breast.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: An alternative name for these is sphero-conical vessels. The function of this very distinctive class of container has attracted many different opinions since the early nineteenth century. They have been interpreted as containers for mercury, fire-blowers (aeolipiles), grenades for containing Greek fire, flasks for containing fizzy alcohol or other liquids, holy water bottles or even lamps, loom-weights or decorative finials used in architecture. They have a very wide distribution stretching from Spain to Central Asia, date between the twelfth and thirteenth centuries, and were made in many different workshops. Whereas most are made of high-fired pottery, some were made of metal and glass. For more information, see: R. Ettinghausen, “The uses of sphero-conical vessels in the Muslim East”, ‘Journal of Near Eastern Studies’, 24/3 (July 1965), pp.218-229.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is a general term for a musical instrument which produces a sound by a vibrating column of air. Wind instruments form the main sub-category.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Unworked lump of copper alloy used as currency.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a sword of the Ashanti peoples - Ghana.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The largest gong of the gamelan.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Do not use this term as an Object Name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term ahuayo (meaning 'woven cloth') refers to a woven cloth from the Andes, which can be used as a baby-carrier,a woman or a man's carrying cloth, a woman's mantle, a ceremonial altar, etc. and the corresponding Object Names should be entered in addition to 'ahuayo'. Strictly speaking, the ahuayo appeared in Colonial times as an adaptation of the former lliqlla (lliclla) garment.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' South America collections this term refers to a cloth frequently used as a garment.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should be multiple-keyworded with DRAWING or PRINT, painting as appropriate. See also the Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term includes all objects relating to either the production or consumption of alcoholic drinks. Generally, Greek and Roman vessels and Oriental ritual vessels have been excluded from this category. Objects involved in the preparation or consumption of punch have been included.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term covers individual letters and sequences of letters.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: An Indian term for a shoulder mantle worn during a religious ritual.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term includes all objects associated with animals apart from HUNTING EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term does not include human remains, see separate term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Small cast bronze coins of ancient China with inscriptions that resemble faces.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be used for drawings which show elevations, sections, groundplans, etc., and that are measured or would be functional to architects. Drawings of architectural features that are integral to a building, such as fire-places or stair-cases, could also be given this object name. Ornamental or free-standing features may not be included in this category.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with Object Name ARCHITECTURE or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term includes HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT, e.g. DRAIN, and all objects forming a structural part of buildings or constructions.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to wool and cotton bed-screens which are suspended along and over the alcove or bed, forming also a mosquito protection by adding another piece of cloth to it. The Arkilla kerka are a prestigious and an essential component of the bride’s trousseau in the Fulbe society and have an extremely important social and symbolic significance.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to wool and cotton bed-screens which are suspended along and over the alcove or bed. They are prestigious and important components of the bride’s trousseau in the Songoy society.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also armlet, arm-ring, bangle and bracelet.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also arm-band, armlet, bangle and bracelet.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Vessels, with a religious or ritual function, found in Cyprus, Anatolia and the Levant, in the Late Bronze Age period.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a narrow device worn on the arm and designed to ward off blows rather than protect the whole body.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is restricted to garments.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a a mount sometimes used to protect glass or porcelain.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also arm-band, arm-ring, bangle and bracelet.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This category is mainly for equipment associated with arms and armour, but this term can be used in its own right.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For associated equipment, see ARMS EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is only entered as an Object Name for arrow heads found on their own. See also records with Object Name 'arrow'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Terms beginning 'paint' may refer to house-painting.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to worked objects of uncertain function. See also 'band'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to 'books' created by artists.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be used in the context of a game; otherwise HUMAN REMAINS should be used.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A quadrant which features curved lines derived from the stereographic projection of the astrolabe including azimuth lines, zodiac lines and a horizon line. This complex instrument can be used for numerous astronomical calculations.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with individual instrument names.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This category includes objects for mechanically recording, transmitting or receiving sound or images, and associated equipment.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Broad blade with scalar retouch on one or both edges. The distal end may be variously shaped but is often retouched to a pointed of narrow rounded form.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The should be entered as an additional Object Name when applied to objects other than clocks and watches, e.g. figures, toys, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers specifically for East Asian objects that serve both as money and as medals.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Copper axe-head shaped item of currency.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to vehicles.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is restricted to armour. For figure backplates, etc. the term BACKPLATE should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the term refers to part of another object, the name of that object should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade with more or less abrupt marginal retouch along all or part of one edge, above the butt. The opposite edge is often unmodified.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bladelet with more or less abrupt marginal retouch along all or part of one edge above the butt. The opposite edge is often unmodified.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a stone blade or flake, one edge blunted, the opposite end used as a knife.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be used for figure backplates, lamp backplates, etc. For armour, the term BACK-PLATE should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If in the form of another object, eg. a staff, the term should be multiple-keyworded with the appropriate object name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Chinese term for a lucky charm in the shape of a lock, placed around a child's neck as a pendant to bring good luck and protection. Baijiasuo translates literally as '[blessed by] 100 families lock'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a woman's head-shawl. In Tunisia it is generally rectangular and covers the head and face.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also the field for Inscription Type.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is used for ball-shaped artefacts and has a specific archaeological meaning for the Department of Prehistory and Europe. See also CRYSTAL BALL and GAME-BALL.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A large bolt or arrow fired from a ballista

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a form of token money in China. Long narrow strips of bamboo with inscriptions (usually giving the name of the issuer and the value of the tally, and sometimes also a serial number and instructions for use).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use a Narrow Term if more appropriate. See also 'artefact'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A square or rectangular piece of cloth used to cover the head or tied around the neck for protective or decorative purposes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also armlet, arm-band, arm-ring, bracelet and wrist-ornament.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the context of the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' North America collections, the term refers to an object which has religious and ceremonial associations.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If known, the name of the whole object should be used instead (e.g. arrow).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an Upper Palaeolithic and Mesolithic bone, antler or ivory projectile tip with barbs on one or both sides. If the barbed point is a spear tip or harpoon tip, enter 'spear' or 'harpoon' as additional Object Names.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an object used in Japanese woodblock printing.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a tightly wound roll of bark which may have served as a net float or as a means of storing the material to be used for making containers or distilling resin.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Barkcloth (bark cloth) is beaten or felted bark. The Object Name barkcloth should be only be entered if the object is a piece of barkcloth with no known use, e.g. a sample. If the object is, e.g. an apron, that term is the Object Name. The term barkcloth is always recorded in the Description. The Material is bark or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A component of a watch movement which is screwed to the movement back-plate to provide bearing for the barrel arbor. Often inscribed with a name and place.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the context of transport.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use bath-tub for the specific object of that name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Some departments may wish to exclude the term BEAD from a retrieval on JEWELLERY used as a Broad Term. Search also under 'bead' (Description) or 'beadwork' (Technique) for beads which are part of other objects, rather than objects in their own right.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, the term refers to a covering placed over the bandaged mummy for decorative or amuletic purposes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: When the object is part of a loom, use the term LOOM.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to false or ornamental beards.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Where the context is weaving, see the Narrow Terms of WEAVING EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a board on which e.g. bark is beaten to produce barkcloth.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a round object, made of ceramic polychrome ware, decorated with various subjects and motifs.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Some departments may wish to exclude the term BELL from a retrieval on MUSICAL INSTRUMENT used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a yoke for suspending a bell (not carrying).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For specific types, e.g. Type A, see the Type Series field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a ladle with a handle for attaching to a belt.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Object records with Object Name BELT or its Narrow Terms should also be consulted.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A likeness of a disease-causing spirit, used to entice the spirit out of a human body and contain it. Of Sarawak (East Malaysia).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is used to gather up anything used to prepare or serve betel.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the whole object should be entered, if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a flat jade disc for ritual use.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term does not refer to a baby's feeding vessel; see BABY-FEEDER.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade with retouch alternately on the dorsal surface of one edge and the ventral surface of the other.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Flake with retouch alternately on the dorsal surface of one edge and the ventral surface of the other.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a weapon, and not a bill of sale.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a type of fastening, and should only be used if the object is found in isolation; otherwise the name of whole object should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Where appropriate, enter the term WHISTLE as well.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a pot in which birds nest.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Glass flask used for tej, Ethiopian honey wine.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to two quite distinct types of objects. The first, more general meaning, is a component of a tool, implement or weapon. Where known, the name of the whole object should be used instead. In stone artefact terminology a blade is a removal struck from a core deliberately prepared so that the detachments have more or less parallel edges and are at least twice as long as they are wide.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In stone artefact terminology a blade is a removal struck from a core deliberately prepared so that the detachments have more or less parallel edges and are at least twice as long as they are wide. A bladelet is smaller than a blade: usually less than 30mm but not more than 50mm long and less than 12mm wide.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a textile from the Plains tribes of North America which has the form of long beaded hide strips interspersed with roundels. It was used to securely wrap the blankets of Plains peoples while they were on the move.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A more specific term should be used if possible.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a book consisting of full-page woodcuts, usually 15thC.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Metal waste from casting or working

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an object used for blowing air to maintain fires; it is not a weapon.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Object records with the Object Name BOAT or its Narrow Terms should also be consulted.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bog body is a term that describes any human remains found in a bog. The cold, acidic conditions of a bog, the lack of oxygen, and the effects of decaying Sphagnum mosses, mean that human remains from bogs are often very well-preserved.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a talismanic pendant from North Africa, the Sahara and sub-Saharan Africa.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to the official tie of Arizona, USA, invented during the 1950s.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the 'nut and bolt' context. If the object is from a cross-bow, use QUARREL; if from a lock, use LOCK; and if a DRAW-BOLT, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to the entire instrument, comprising a frame and kettle gongs used in gamelan.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a small fancy box to hold sweets.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should be used for entire books and also for pages extracted from them, apart from: book-illustrations, colophons, frontispieces ad title-pages which have their own Object Names.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a group of related prints bound together as a presentation or gift volume, without text; usually from the end of the 18thC to mid-19thC.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term does not refer to furniture.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should not be used for the Department of Prints and Drawings; BOOK-ILLUSTRATION should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Prints and Drawings, the term is entered as an Object Name for prints extracted from books (or proofs for illustrations), including head-pieces, tail-pieces, vignettes and other book decorations (apart from frontispieces and title-pages which are terms in their own right, under the Broad Term 'book-illustration'.). For Japanese woodblock printed illustrated books, the term is entered for a printed page extracted from an illustrated book. See also the Object Name 'illustrated book'. For vignettes on papyri, check the Description field, as these are not recorded as Object Name 'book-illustration', but only as 'papyrus'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A more specific term should be used if possible.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the whole object should be used, if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Lime-spatula made of whale bone or turtle shell.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the context of weapons. See also MUSICAL BOW for music, and BOW-STRING for unidentified bow-strings.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the term refers to a MUSICAL BOW, use that term. If from a weapon, use BOW.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a stand for a bowl. When it is both a BOWL and a STAND, enter both terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bracelets can be worn on the wrist or arm. The term 'wrist-ornament' has BT: 'arm-ornament' so records for bracelets can be searched for under either BT as well as under 'bracelet'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For objects described as 'bracteates'. See also BRACTEATE COIN, BRACTEATE DISC, and BRACTEATE PENDANT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to carpentry.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a girdle for confining a hawk's wings.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'breakfast-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to personal ornaments. If more appropriate, HARNESS should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with other object names, as appropriate, e.g. spear.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to money made of bronze, associated with bronze spade-money and knife-money of ancient China.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A collective name for the pans and fire bars used in the making of salt through evaporation

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to single sheet with letterpress, most of those in the British Museum have images. Includes slip broadsides.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a coin which has been struck while a previous coin adhered to the striking die, so that a negative impression of one side is imprinted onto the coin.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: As a rule, the Narrow Terms of BROOCH have been used for the collections in the Department of Prehistory and Europe. See also under FIBULA for the Department of Greece and Rome.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is a HAIR-BRUSH, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a hanging stand for writing and painting brushes in a Korean scholar's studio.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an object used to shape the tip of a brush and to remove excess water or ink.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Object records with the Object Name BUCKLE or its Narrow Terms should also be consulted.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Dihedral burin on which the transverse part is formed by several burin facets which are usually convex in profile and stopped by a retouched notch. Characteristic of the Aurignacian.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Burin made on blades or bladelets with abrupt backing retouch. The backing is used to provide the striking platform for the burin removal. Characteristic of Epi-Palaeolithic assemblages in North Africa.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade or flake on which a break has been used as the striking platform from which a burin spall has been removed, perpendicular or slightly oblique to the axis of the break.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Burin made on an abrupt retouched truncation which is straight and oblique to the axis of the piece.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is part of a SMOKING-PIPE, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also veil and its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Tanged point found in Neolithic assemblages in the Near East fashioned on a blade. It is characterised by a tang that is generally not much narrower than the body and which is off-set from the body by an angle of more than 90 degrees (usually greater than 120). The tang tends to be retouched (often through pressure flaking) whilst the body and the point tend to be sparsely worked.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to photograph mounted on card, similar to, but larger than, a carte-de-visite. Despite the similarity, the cabinet format was used for landscape and other views before it was adopted for portraiture.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is not restricted to machines.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to measures.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Records for such objects should, where appropriate, include an additional Object Name, such as 'scroll', etc. and in all cases, the Subject 'calligraphy'. No Technique should be entered for objects which are regarded as 'calligraphy', unless also described as 'painting', etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a stone (or shell, glass, glass paste, and other materials) of two or more layers, usually of different colour, which have been carved away to produce an image in relief. However, the term is also used for stones of one colour worked in the same way and for moulded glass or ceramic cameos.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade with a trapezoidal cross-section detached from a unipolar blade core. Characteristic of the early and middle Bronze Age in the Levant.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with Object Name CANOE or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should not be used for the Department of Ancient Eygpt and the Sudan; see CANOPIC JAR.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to head-gear. See also LID.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A small hook with decorative element on the front and single S-shaped hook soldered onto the back. Often enamelled, studded with gems and pearls, or made in relief in bronze, silver or gold. Worn on the kind of man's black felt hat as worn at the very end of the 15th Century and into the 1530s in Europe.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used if the object occurs in isolation; otherwise use COLUMN or PILLAR.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a tool used for raising the nap (pile) on the surface of a felted or knitted object. In Tunisia carding tools are used to raise the nap on the surface of chechias (men's skull-caps).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Burin on which the transverse part is formed by several elongated burin facets which are convex in profile and frequently twisted.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: End scraper made on a thick, domed flake modified by shallow, parallel-sided removals to form a steep scraper front.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Scraper made on a thick, domed flake modified by steep, invasive, parallel-sided removals.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also Object records with Object Name CARRIAGE or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: When the object is a head-strap, use TUMP-LINE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. See also Object records with Object Name CART or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a small portrait photograph mounted on a card.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the context of both frescoes and paintings, and should not be confused with MODERN CARTOON.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A plastic card used for transactions from a credit based account.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the Object Name of the original. Any other details of the original should only be entered in the Description and Associated fields.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to furniture.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: An additional Object Name of painting or sculpture should be added as appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a textile garment worn by both men and women in parts of South Asia and the Muslim world. When worn by women it is used to cover the head and shoulders, while men drape it around their shoulders. See also head-shawl and headscarf.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Do not use this term in the Department of Prehistory and Europe; use MAIL-ARMOUR.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is generally restricted to a religious context except for in classical Greek and Roman settings where the usage is more defined by form.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a key which is the emblem of membership of the Royal Household.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade or flake which exhibits an oblique transverse removal at the distal end. They are found amongst Levantine and North African Upper Palaeolithic assemblages.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Korean chess-board.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Korean chess-piece.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Changgi is Korean chess. The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'changgi-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a small cheap book made of poor quality paper and sewn together without covers. Chapbooks were sold widely between the late 17th century and early 19h century.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A more specific term should be used if possible, e.g. BELT-FITTING, BUCKLE-FITTING, STRAP-FITTING.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to vessels, but has been used interchangeably with PLATTER. Use PRIMING-FLASK where appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Also check Object records with Object Name CHARIOT or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a man's woollen skull-cap made in Tunisia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, the term applies to an undershirt.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A plastic card used to guarantee payment of a customer's cheque, up to the specified amount.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a container, common in Burma, for storing cheroots. They are frequently decorated with lacquer and in shape often follow that of the cheroot, being tall and thin.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'chess-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a square textile, made in Palestine, that is heavily embroidered and made to be sewn onto the front of a dress or shirt.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A Japanese term which refers to a straight sword, but similar in construction to the tachi.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a stone pebble with unifacial or bifacial flaking on one edge.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the context is culinary, also enter the additional term CULINARY EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the context is culinary, also enter the additional term CULINARY EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prints and Drawings, the term refers to engraved historical and genealogical lineages, e.g. kings, popes, Roman emperors, noble families, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is a generic term for a large piece of lithic debitage. It can also be used in glass studies to describe fragment of glass moved in non-ingot form for use in making objects.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a musical instrument from Zambia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has been used interchangeably with FUNERARY URN in some departmental records.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: End scraper on a circular flake with retouch around the entire circumference.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If part of bell, use BELL. In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, double-key with DANCING EQUIPMENT and/or RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If referring to a type of ammunition, use PELLET.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is restricted to cleats from boats.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an object used for tree-climbing.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to ash and partially fused residues from a coal fired furnace or fire.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has been used interchangeably with TEXTILE in the documentation.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Projectile point characterised by tapering parallel-slightly convex edges and concave base; both faces are entirely modified by flat, sub-parallel retouch. The points are thinned by the removal of a flake along the long axis from the base on both faces. These 'flutes' vary in length and enabled hafting. Clovis points are specific to the earliest settlers in North America.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is KILN-FURNITURE, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'coffee-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Check also Object records with 'coffin' and its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Cap, often with a black veil, that covers the hair; used in Tunisia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term covers two types of object: either a coin perforated and strung onto a necklace, collar or garment, or suspended through an added suspension loop or bead; or, a pendant set with a coin in a decorative frame.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is used to make clay coin-moulds.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Some coins were cast in strips prior to being struck and then separated.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is a device with slots to check that coins are of the correct thickness.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A form of talisman used in southern China to drive away evil. Made from brass cash coins attached to an iron rod using lucky red string.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: It is assumed that colanders are used for culinary purposes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: An image made by pasting pieces of paper, or similar material (usually cut out), to a backing.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should only be used when it refers to a neck ornament. When the object is part of a garment, the name of the garment should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This refers to a page in a book giiving details of publication.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use for commercially produced colouring books for children.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term has generally been used in the sense of 'hair-comb' but this may not be the case for all examples. See Related terms for other types of comb.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to cases for hair-combs.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is restricted to the instrument used in orientation. See also COMPASSES.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: An elongated stone, bone or antler tool used to detach or retouch flakes and blades by pressure. The removals are pressed off rather than struck off with a percussive hammer action. Compressors may also be used to rub down and thereby adjust the edge of a striking plaform. The working end is usually blunted/rounded by use. These tools are common in the later Upper Palaeolithic.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is a TRUMPET, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Probably used for sauces, but may have been used for salt or spices. See also the terms 'cruet-set' and 'condiment-dish'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Probably used for sauces, but may have been used for salt or spices. See also the terms 'cruet-set' and 'condiment-bowl'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Minoan cup, conical in shape, usually with a flat base. Made in large quantities.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to architecture.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Also check object records with CONTAINER or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Coin-like token or medallion produced in the 4th and 5th century AD, with a distinctive raised rim. The function of this type of object is uncertain, but they often depict subjects related to public spectacles and games. Earlier emperors and other historical figures are sometimes portrayed on the obverse.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a ceremonial symbol of wealth, and should only be used for the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' North American collections.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to preserved or fossilised faeces of an animal or human.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be used for a stringed musical instrument when a more specific term is not available. It has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to the residual objects from which stone tools were made.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the striking platform on a core has become unusable or exhausted further removals may become impossible and to continue working it is necessary to restore it by the removal of a rejuvenation flake. Such flakes are struck from the face of the core to remove the old platform. They have a tabular form with steep edges formed by remnants of the scars left by the detachment of blades or bladelets around the core face.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Face of a blade or bladelet core detached as a flake in process of rejuvenation.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Flake removed from the face of a core enable the removal of blades to continue.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is ceramic, the term STORAGE-VESSEL should also be entered as an Object Name in the Object record.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the Department of the Middle East and does not refer to a musical instrument.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, the term may refer to a head-band or head-dress.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to armour.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'cosmetic-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to the applicator.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: From the 16th century onwards, series of costume prints were produced showing figures in the dress of different nations and classes. Fashion prints, or plates, develop out of these, but their purpose was to show the latest in fashion. They were commonly published in monthly or weekly series.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a circular costume accessory.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to objects which are intended to be attached to costume, and should only be used when such objects occur in isolation. Check also Object records with COSTUME or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Tray with compartment(s) for holding game counters.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the whole object should be entered instead, when available.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the counterproof is taken from a print.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is a board with a grid of holes, for counting coins.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Where more appropriate, the term LID should be used. For the Department of Prints and Drawings, this term includes book-jackets, magazine-covers, portfolio-covers, etc., and should not be multiple-keyworded with BOOK-ILLUSTRATION. See also MUSIC-COVER.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This refers to a specific type of cup which has an integral cover, with a hole for drinking.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Cowrie is a recognised term for a type of currency, ie. cowrie shells.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Meissen porcelain shape.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A plastic card used for transactions from a credit based account.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bladelet with an evenly curved, convex backed edge formed by direct abrupt retouch. Crescents occur in the Late Stone Age throughout Africa and continue in use into the Neolithic, whilst in the Levant they are commonly found in Epi-palaeolithic assemblages. They are also known as lunates and segments.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade with removal scars forming a ridge along the mid-line of the dorsal surface and a triangualr cross-section. The ridge is usually formed by bi-directional flaking or uni-directional removals from a natural surface. Crested blades are diagnostic of the early stage of core preparation during which guide ridges must be established to enable the detachment of long, narrow blanks to be made into tools.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bladelet with removal scars forming a ridge along the mid-line of the dorsal surface and a triangular cross-section. The ridge is usually formed by bi-directional flaking or uni-directional removals from a natural surface. Crested bladelets are diagnostic of the early stages of bladelet core preparation during which guide ridges must be established to enable the detachment of narrow blanks to be used to make bladelet tools.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Flake with removal scars forming a ridge along the mid-line of the dorsal surface and a triangular cross-section. The ridge is usually formed by bi-directional flaking or uni-directional removals from a natural surface. Crested flakes are diagnostic of the early stages of blade/bladelet core preparation during which guide ridges must be established to enable the detachment of narrow blanks to be used to make blade/bladelet tools.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Point with angle on the backed edge formed by convergence of backing with an oblique retouched truncation. The edge opposite the backing forms a distal point where it converges with the truncation. The butt is modified to form a proximal point and backing may continue a short distance up the otherwise unmodified edge.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a knife with a blade set at a sharp angle to the handle. Commonly used by the First Peoples of Sub-Arctic and northeastern North America.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If Christ is depicted, the term CRUCIFIX should be used instead of CROSS, although this practice has not always been followed.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also Object records with Object Name 'cross-bow'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to crosses bearing the figure of Christ; otherwise use the term CROSS. This practice has not been followed in all cases, and retrievals should be made under both terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term originally referred to a small bottle or vial for liquids, now used to refer to vessels for vinegar, oil, etc. for the table, with a stopper. If the cruet is a bottle, also enter that term as an Object Name. See also the terms 'cruet-set', 'condiment-dish' and 'condiment-bowl'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a small vessel for wine or water for celebrating the Eucharist, or for holy water for other uses.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component, e.g. 'cruet', 'cruet-stand', mustard-pot', 'pepper-pot', 'salt-shaker', should be entered as well as the term 'cruet-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to wrist ornaments. If from a GARMENT, that term or a specific garment name (e.g. SHIRT) should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to objects used in cooking and food preparation. See also VESSEL and its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is a hybrid between a cup and a kantharos.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is a hybrid betwen a cup and a skyphos.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional Object Name, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional Object Name, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be as an additional Object Name, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This category includes issued currency and non-issued media of exchange. It should be multiple-keyworded with other Object Names, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Also check Object records with CURTAIN or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade with direct steep backing retouch beginning above the butt on one edge. The opposite edge is unmodified. The curved backed edge may be convex or concave but never C-shaped as on a crescent.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade or bladelet modified by steep, direct backing retouch on one side and an unmodified edge opposite. The curve of the modified edge may be convex or concave.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade or bladelet on which the curved distal end has been formed by direct abrupt - semi abrupt retouch. The curvature of the retouch and continuity of the edge distinguishes this tool type from a distal truncation.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to rectanglar shaped seals produced in Middle to Bronze Age Crete.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe the term refers to a cuboid or sub-cuboid stone with one or more faces ground, perhaps with traces of rubbing or polishing from use; known in Bronze Age contexts.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also Object records for KNIFE, FORK and SPOON, since a large number are probably items of cutlery, but have not been identified as such.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is restricted to tablets. For cylinder-shaped objects, use ARTEFACT, or a more specific Object Name such as TUBE, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A Japanese term which refers to a pair of swords in matching fittings worn together: dai- being the long sword, and sho- being the shorter companion sword. Only the samurai were permitted to wear them during the Edo period.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Personal ornament usually worn on the head comprising a shell-disk with an overlay of fretted turtle-shell secured by a hole in the centre, as made in Solomon Islands.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A plastic card used for direct transactions from cleared funds in an account.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Waste flakes and cores produced in the manufacture of stone implements.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of the Middle East this term may apply to pottery vessels.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Section of antler used to support engraved drawings of animals and/or incised patterns. Decorated antlers are well known with the art of the Upper Palaeolithic and also occur occasionally in Mesolithic and Neolithic contexts.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bone decorated with engraved or low relief animal figures or patterns. Upper Palaeolithic.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also the Materials term GOURD.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be used for items such as marbled paper, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the Department of the Middle East, and refers to an inscribed cone inserted between bricks of buildings.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a stone flake or blade with a denticulated and retouched edge.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used for planting equipment.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use dice for the game-piece; see also die.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should not be used in the context of games or gaming; see also DICE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade or flake which has a small edge formed by the intersection of two or more burin facets.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Food storage and preparation bag, used by indigenous Australian peoples.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'dinner-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional Object Name, if appropriate. See also DIPTYCH PRINT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a flat bead, made using the lost wax method of casting from precious metal, and worn as part of composite necklaces, bracelets and anklets by the Akan-speaking peoples of Ghana and the Baule of Côte D’Ivoire. It should be added as an additional Object Name to the item it is part of, e.g. 'necklace', where known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: ME - for clay cuneiform examples, also enter TABLET.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to documents whether made of paper, clay, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Greece and Rome this term refers to a large storage-jar.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object functions as a TOY, that term should be entered as an additional Object Name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'domino-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: It is assumed that the term refers to architecture; if from furniture, a more appropriate term should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. Check also records with Object Name DOOR.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Upper Palaeolithic point/projectile tip made from bone, antler or ivory which first appear during the Aurignacian but are more frequent in the Middle & Late Magdalenian. Circular in cross-section, the edges are straight tapering slightly to a point at one end and the base is thinned by cutting a flat-slightly concave longitudinal facet (bevel) on two sides. The bevelled end may be slightly pointed, rounded or straight. The bevels may be marked by diagonal, horizontal or longitudinal striations.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade or flake modified by retouch forming a more or less rounded front at both the proximal and distal ends.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Flake modified by retouch on opposite edges. The retouch is usually scalar, marginal-semi-invasive forming straight, convex or concave shape. The retouched edges do not converge and are not connected by retouch across the distal end.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a coin which has been struck more than once and has moved in the die in between strikings so that part of the design is visible twice or more.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use the name of the whole object when appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This refers to notes recording money drawn from a bank account.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: P&D watercolours are regarded as drawings; for that department do not use the term painting.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a compilation of prints, often in outine, used by students of drawing. The term 'sketch-book' is used for a blank book in which drawings are made, and

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'drawing-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A drawplate is a thick steel plate with many holes of reducing diameters through which wire can be drawn (or pulled) sequentially to make it thinner to achieve or produce the wire diameter needed for the particular jewellery components that are required to construct and embellish the finished object. A typical drawplate may have twenty holes which allows a wide range of wire diameters to be made to suit various purposes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a charm, of North American Indian origin, consisting of a wooden or leather hoop with a webbed centre of threads decorated with feathers, beads, etc., and usually hung above a bed to entrap bad dreams.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the term refers to an object used in making clothing, use PIN and enter the additional term NEEDLEWORK EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to core and other waste from vessel-making processes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Do not specify types of drugs in the Object Name field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If a part of another object, enter the name of that object.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Narrow bladelet which often has a curved profile and is modified by either direst or inverse retouch on one edge only or, on both edges by alternate retouch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to any form of imitation watch ranging from pewter ‘toy’ watches of the 17th century through pottery and enamel examples from the 18th century worn by women as dummies to pair with real watches, to 20th century chocolate watches and a plastic watch puzzles.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a scarf worn by Muslim women in India, and by Punjabis.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter the constituents, if known, in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a picture sign-board, often for theatre.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a spool-shaped ear-ornament.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Used for vessels wtih sole function of food consumption

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Term used to describe a watch movement which could be purchased from a supplier in various states of completion ranging from simple plates, pillars and balance-cock etc to a completely finished watch movement. Generally the ebauches were supplied with unfinished pivots and without any components of the escapement. Ebauches were purchased by "watchmakers" to be finished by skilled watchmakers ready for dialling and casing up for retail.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A tool with a cutting or pounding edge made by bifacial retouch

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is used in the context of fishing.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a 'picture' calendar, a type of Japanese woodblock print with calendrical marks hidden in the design.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bladelets or small blades which display fine minimally invasive retouch along lateral margins to form a point. They are found amongst Levantine Upper Palaeolithic assemblages.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Strictly speaking, the term refers to an exact metallic copy usually made as a one-off from a mould of an original by an electrochemical process (generally referred to as electroforming), a basic plating process aided by an electrical source, in which metal (usually copper) ions migrate through an electrolytic solution and are 'deposited' into a mould on which the ions gradually build to form the shape and detail of the original. However, the use of the term in the British Museum records is broadened to include any metal copy (ie. not only the one-off copy) of the original, produced by this process. The term 'electrotype' is entered as an Object Name as well as the Object Name of the original, and the term 'electroformed' is entered in the Technique field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If part of another object, also enter the name of that object.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a non-specific tool used for embroidery, and has been used as a Broad Term as well.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade or flake with continuous retouch around one end forming a more or less rounded front.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: End scraper on a large, broad blade characteristic of Aurignacian technology. One or both edges of the blade may also carry scalar retouch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade which displays retouch confined to the proximal or distal end.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: End scraper on a wide flake of variable size with a front which sometimes extends all the way around the periphery, excluding the butt which is always unretouched.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: End scraper on a blade with continuous retouch on one or both edges.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: End scraper on a blade or flake with retouch on one or both edges

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Tool combining any type of endscraper with any type of burin on the same flake or blade.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use for Palaeolithic (mobiliary) art items engraved on bone or antler.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term does not refer to the type used in photography.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: ME - for the clay cases of cuneiform tablets, use the term TABLET-CASE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a naturally modified flint, which resembles early tools. There are large numbers of them in the Palaeolithic/Mesolithic collections of the Prehistory and Europe Department.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Greece and Rome this term refers to a thigh-guard used in the preparation of wool.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Because of the earth’s angle to the sun and its elliptical path round it there is a difference between apparent solar time and mean solar time. An equation table allows an observer to read the apparent solar time on a sundial and then according to the date on the table add or subtract the equation figure to arrive at the mean solar time. Solar Time agrees with Mean Time on April 16th, June 15th, September 1st and December 25th.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term 'equestrian' covers horses, mules, and donkeys. See also under other Narrow Terms of ANIMAL EQUIPMENT, such as SADDLE, etc. and under SPUR.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a method of print collecting that involves assembling prints of people, events and places, and binding them into a special copy of a book such that the prints illustrate the text. Texts that were popular with such collectors were the Rev.J.Granger's 'Biographical History of England' (whence the term 'Grangerising' for such collecting) and the Earl of Clarendon's 'History of the Rebellion and Civil Wars in England'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Glass beads with decoration formed by applied concentric blobs of different colours.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an eye made of semi-precious material removed from a statue, often with an inscription on it, used as a bead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a rod-like flint implement, possibly for making sparks.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an object made with a deliberate attempt to deceive. The Object Name of the original should be entered as an addtional keyword. See also IMITATION.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the case of fans of the European type, the term 'fan' is used whether or not the fan has been mounted on sticks; the term 'print' or 'drawing' is added as appropriate. The term 'fan-print' is used for Japanese woodblock prints designed for use as fans, but not necessarily mounted on sticks.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the case of fans of the European type, the term 'fan' is used whether or not the fan has been mounted on sticks; the term 'print' or 'drawing' is added as appropriate. The term 'fan-print' is used for Japanese woodblock prints designed for use as fans, but not necessarily mounted on sticks.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A single-edged hafted weapon with hook projecting from back of blade.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term 'figure' is generally used for representations of animate subjects (e.g. 'dancer') and the term 'model' for inanimate ones (e.g. 'amphora').

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with Object Name FIGURE or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a single shot from a film (or a specially posed photograph of a scene from it) for use in advertising.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This covers all object names relating to banking and paper currency.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also RING and its Narrow Terms, since some finger-rings may not yet have been identified as such.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is restricted to architecture; use TERMINAL for other contexts.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to cutlery. See also the term FISHING-KNIFE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This category also includes objects used for fishing crustacea, molluscs, etc. For whaling equipment, including harpoons, see HUNTING EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should only be used for unspecified fitting. The names of specific types of fitting should only be used for important collections of such objects, otherwise the most appropriate broader category is entered, e.g. VESSEL-FITTING.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is assumed to refer to agriculture. See also RITUAL FLAIL.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In stone artefact terminology a flake is the product detached when a hammer is used to modify another piece or nodule of stone. Many flakes are simply waste products (debitage) produced during knapping; some may subsequently be modified by retouch and are then defined and named as various types of tools.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an object used for cutting-up or flaying whales or seals.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to objects used with a steel to light a fire. For tools made of flint, see TOOL/IMPLEMENT and its Narrow Terms. For miscellaneous samples of flint, use SAMPLE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Name of a kind of money used in Burma.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object also functions as a TOY, enter that term as an additional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This has not been used as a BT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the tool.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is not a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an object made with a deliberate attempt to deceive. The Object Name of the original should be entered as an addtional keyword. See also IMITATION.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A fossil is a preserved remain of a previously living organism (plant or animal). Leaves, cockle shells, bones, wood, coprolites, etc may all be preserved as fossils. They may be preserved or partially preserved as all sorts of different materials, e.g. calcite, pyrite, limonite, amber, etc. If the specific material of which the fossil is composed is not known, then no Material should be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should be multiple-keyworded with the name of the specific object, if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Minaoan seal.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is under the Broad Term sculpture as well as under architecture, because in most instances the British Museum friezes (or parts) are in relief. For textiles, use WALL-HANGING or another term from the thesaurus.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should only be used when the object from which the fringe came is not known. See also GARMENT and its Narrower Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to harness; for human use, see HEAD-BAND.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Conical objects of fired clay used to create decorative friezes over the entrances to tombs of the New Kingdom, especially at Thebes. The cones were set into the wall in rows to leave the circular blunt end visible, which was stamped with an inscription giving the name and titles of the tomb-owner.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This Broad Term includes equipment used during the process of embalming.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has been used interchangeably with CINERARY URN in some departmental records.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Some departments may wish to exclude the term TEMPLE-HANGING from retrievals under FURNISHING or HANGING.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. Also check records with Object Name FURNITURE or its NTs.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Mask attached to apex of house or storehouse.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should only be used for unspecified games. See also game-piece and game-board.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For searches for board games, see also the Narrow Terms of game-piece.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is used to refer to the set of instruments and associated equipment used in Indonesian music and ritual. If the Object Name is not a Narrow Term of 'gamelan', that term should be added as an additional Object Name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The category includes objects used in sports, games and gaming (gambling).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be used in the context of gambling.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: It is not clear whether the term refers to a charm or a gaming-piece.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the context of gambling.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is restricted to Personal Ornament; see also WREATH and FUNERARY WREATH.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Some terms regarded as garments under certain classification systems have been entered in the PERSONAL ACCESSORY hierarchy.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A garniture is a set of matching vessels of uneven number, usually varying from five to nine pieces, made for display on the mantelpiece, on brackets and cornices of walls, and in cupboards and cabinets of European houses (Harrison-Hall and Krahl 1994).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a ritual mask of the Gola people.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term has been used in some records to refer to a gemstone which has been worked. The more specific terms cameo and intaglio are used in preference to gem as Object Names, but such objects have traditionally been published as gems in the British Museum catalogues. See also Material gemstone.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Textiles produced using the double ikat technique. Produced in the village of Tenganan Pageringsingan, Bali, Indonesia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a waist garment, but has the Broad TERM 'belt' as it is so defined in the OED. See also 'corset'. N.B. In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, the term 'girdle' refers to a string of beads, shells, etc., sometimes found at the waist in burial contexts. In such cases, the additional term 'jewellery' should be entered as an Object Name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a pendant suspended from a woman's girdle or belt, and usually resembling a pair of latchlifter-type keys in Anglo-Saxon regions, or sometimes single discs on the Continent.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a mezzotint pasted to glass, hand-coloured and then framed.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to photographic slides, not microscope slides.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to animal goads.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' Oceania collections this term refers to a non-figurative stick symbolising God.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Gold-weights were used to weigh out measures of gold dust in West Africa before the arrival of European traders on the coast in the late fifteenth century. The majority of gold-weights were created by the Akan-speaking communities that lived on the Gold Coast (now modern-day Ghana). They are made using the lost wax casting method from brass (an alloy of copper) and can be abstract or figurative in form.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an armoured throat-piece; where the object is a a personal ornament use NECK-ORNAMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Tool used for the process of grinding.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a small metal ring used to reinforce an eyelet through which a fastener may be passed. It should only be entered when the object is found in isolation and the object it originated from is unknown.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a pebble or piece of stone usually about 6-10 cm long with a broad, U-shaped groove on the long axis of one or both faces. The inner surface of the groove is smooth but may show some fine longitudinal striations resulting from another material such as wood or sinew being moved back and forth within the channel. Often called arrow or shaft straighteners, grooved stones are not culturally or chronologically diagnostic. They occur in the Late Stone Age and more recent contexts in Southern Africa, in Late Palaeolithic to Early Bronze Age contexts in Europe, as well as being known in Australia and South Asia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This does not include ARMOUR. See under that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a rose-water sprinkler of disctinctive Indian shape.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Ethiopian dress used by older women at weddings to indicate status.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A quadrant used to measure the angle of elevation of guns to calculate firing ranges.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter the constituents, if known, in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A device used to test the strength of gunpowder.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A specific type of horary quadrant named after Edmund Gunter who proposed this design in 1623. In addition to finding the time of day, this instrument could be used to make several calculations about the position of the Sun throughout the year or determine the times of sunrise and sunset. This popular design also enabled one to tell the time the night, either by measuring the position of prominent stars or by aligning a simple map of the stars on the reverse of the instrument with the orientation of the stars seen above.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a collar around the sword blade and above the tang.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Arabic word, variant hubb, meaning water-jar.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to cut-down scraps of gold used as bullion or for recasting. An additional Object Name should be entered if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is derived from the German word hacksilber and refers to scrap silver used as bullion or melted down for recasting. An additional Object Name should be entered if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should only be entered when it is specifically used by the maker.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Only enter this term if the hand-guard is found in isolation; otherwise enter the name of the whole object.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter the name of the whole object if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Records for such objects should include an additional Object Name such as 'painting', 'drawing', 'print', 'rubbing' or 'calligraphy', and the corresponding technique in Techniques.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Records for such objects should include an additional Object Name such as 'painting', 'drawing', 'print', 'rubbing' or 'calligraphy', and the corresponding technique in Techniques.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term hansatsu ('clan notes') refers to a type of paper money issued in Japan.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. Also check records with Object Name HARNESS or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A Latin term for 'harpagon' (archaic term) which is a grappling-hook.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter the name of the whole object if possible.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: When the term refers to animal equipment, use TRAPPINGS or its Narrow Terms. For the Department of Prints and Drawings use the term BOOK-ILLUSTRATION instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter the term if the object is an ornament, but enter LOAD-CARRIER if more appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, where the object is used as a FIRE-STICK, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to imitation paper money made specifically in the Chinese world for burning to the ancestors. The act of burning it serves as the means of conveying the value to the other world for use there.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a type of mask worn over the head.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Tanged point found in Neolithic assemblages in the Near East fashioned on a blade or bladelet, rarely on a flake. It is characterised by one or more pairs of bilateral notches, and a tang which is small in proportion to the body.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter the name of the whole object if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is generic and refers to a a large rectangular textile, usually of cotton, though sometimes of silk, used in South and Southeast Asia as a garment for the lower body.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object also functions as a TOY, enter that term as an additional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: 'Hoe' is the Maori name for a paddle.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is a Broad Term mainly for terms incorporating 'holder', as used in curatorial documentation.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Stone arrowhead with barbs formed by a retouched notch at the base. The width and depth of the concavity forming the barbed base varies according to blank type, raw material, period and region. The hollow provides the fixing point for the arrow shaft in place of a tang. Hollow based arrowheads are found in the Neolithic of Europe and Africa.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to Chinese red money paper envelopes for children at ceremonies.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to head-gear; see also COVER.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term FASTENER should be used for clothing and the term HOOK for implements.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an Anglo-Saxon dress fitting.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A quadrant used to measure the height of the Sun in the sky. The time is determined by measuring the position of a bead on a plumb bob against a series of curved equal or unequal hour lines.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Coin-shaped game-pieces used in the Chinese board-game Da Ma ('Driving the Horses').

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Type of Mesolithic British flint tool.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a category of object produced by banknote printers, showing their security printing techniques. Although not technically a banknote, it has the Broad Term banknote, as anyone searching for the latter would expect to retrieve house note as well.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a tiered, round-topped vessel for holding offerings.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Burmese women's skirt cloth, a longyi.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter the name of the whole object if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term 'human remains' as an Object Name is only recorded in certain cases for this type of collection. The following rules apply. - Human remains in the form of (or forming part of) objects such as drums, shields, etc., have those Object Names recorded (ie. 'drum', 'shield', etc.). - In cases where such Object Names do not apply, the Narrow Terms of 'human remains' are entered (e.g. 'bog body'). - If neither of these two options apply, the term 'human remains' itself is recorded as an Object Name. 'Human remains' are defined as whole bodies (or parts of bodies), bones, organs and tissue, as well as hair and nails. To retrieve all records for 'human remains' across the database, the term 'human remains' with its Narrow Terms should be searched for in the Materials field, where they are always entered for this type of collection, regardless of the Object Name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This includes objects associated with hunting for sport as well as for subsistence. See also FISHING EQUIPMENT, GAMES AND SPORTS and WEAPON categories.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Used in the Department of the Middle East.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The category refers to objects used to convey or direct a water supply. See also IRRIGATION EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a a carved wooden figure made by the Yoruba people as a substitute for a deceased twin.

binding.name: scope
