binding.literal: Any image of a sacred personage or subject in the Orthodox Church, mainly painted on a portable wood panel. Other media can be of textile, leather, metal, glass.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Ceremonial items which are used by Ainu men when honouring the gods / spirits. They are made of carved wood. Designs include animals and boats as well as geometric patterns. Names used for these articles in the literature on the Ainu include 'mustache stick', 'mustache lifter', libation wand' and 'prayer stick'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal:
The term refers in the premodern period to Japanese woodblock-printed books, where text and images are created by the same technical process, on the same woodblocks. The term is also used for books in the Western tradition that have a number of pictorial illustrations (not merely a frontispiece or decorative ornaments).
See 'book-illustration' for a printed page extracted from an illustrated book; and also 'photobook' and 'artist book'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Imborivungu belong to the category of akombo (power objects), used by the Tiv people in Nigeria. Imborivungu are related to ancestral cult rituals, and are either for the lineage (or kin group), or the individual.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an object which is generally a copy of a design, technique or style, e.g. coin pendants which are more or less loosely based on coins, or archaeological revival objects which copy antique finds, etc. The Object Name of the original should be entered as an addtional keyword. See also FAKE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Sacred shaved sticks, they are said to symbolise birds and send prayers on their way to the spirit world.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter the constituents, if known, in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter the constituents, if known, in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a porcelain screen.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term represents a specific category for the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan. In other cases, only use the term when the object it once formed part of is unknown.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter the constituents, if known, in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to stone or glass (or other materials) into which an image or text has been cut or incised. These texts or images are sometimes cut in reverse in order to produce a positive impression for use as a stamp or seal.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a specific type of cup, not just a cup from Ionia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is not used as a Broad Term, and specific Object Names occur under HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT. It should be multiple-keyworded with another Object Name as appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: An island dress is a type of dress made and worn in Melanesia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Three sided microlith on which two sides are retouched; two edges are the same length, whilst the angles opposite the two equal sides are also the same.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: When the term refers to armour, use COAT-OF-MAIL.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Javelins can be used for war or sports.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a hooded tunic, and should not be confused with JELLABIA.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a full length garment, not hooded; it should not be confused with JELLABA.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Tanged point found in Neolithic assemblages in the Near East fashioned on a straight, non-curved or twisted blade (most probably from an opposed platform core). It is characterised by a tang off-set from the body by an angle of 90 degrees or less and by down turned barbs which are either pointed or of narrow rectangular form.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The additional term ARMOUR should be entered, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For maximum retrieval, search under PERSONAL ORNAMENT and its Narrow Terms. Some departments may wish to exclude the term BEAD from a retrieval on JEWELLERY used as a Broad Term. See also PIN and its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. Also check records with Object Name JEWELLERY.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Short tunic worn by men; close-fitting garment worn by women; used in Middle East, North Africa and Sudan.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Chinese drinking game.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a type of Japanese spear.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should only be entered when it is specifically used by the maker.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In Malaysia, the kain panjang ('long cloth'), is worn around the lower body. Unlike the sarong, it is not sewn, but wrapped around the waist, often with a belt or sash.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Burmese wall-hanging, or curtain, often made of a mixture of local and imported materials.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Burmese. 'A receptacle of lacquered wood or bamboo raised on a pedestal or on feet. Gifts are placed on it in ceremonies of presentation or donation.' (Isaacs and Blurton 2000: p. 235).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object also functions as a TOY, that term should be entered as an additional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a gourd-shaped water vessel, carried by ascetics.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Personal ornament comprising a shell-disk with an overlay of fretted turtle-shell secured by a hole in the centre, as made in Papua New Guinea.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Lime-spatula used for kula exchange and sorcery.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a short, squat and spouted water vessel, usually made of ceramic, and associated with Southeast Asia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A circular tube fitted with rows of miniature cups along the top, which may have been used in rituals.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a drinking cup made of wood with no handle, comparable to a beaker, used mostly by the Incas.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term generally refers to a vessel, usually made of metal, for boiling water or other liquids, or to a pot or caldron. Arctic kettles are made of stone, often rectangular with open tops. They are used to melt snow and to boil water (and sometimes other liquids, such as soup) over fire.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For combined finger-rings with keys, see KEY-FINGER-RING.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If necessary, enter the additional keyword ARCHITECTURE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Since most kites in the collections are used for recreation, the term KITE has been included in the GAMES/SPORTING EQUIPMENT category. See also FISHING-KITE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Knitting-pins are used for weaving, not knitting; see also KNITTING-NEEDLE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to the object used in the game with jacks.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a typical vessel of Kengtung, in the eastern Shan States. Based on a plain rice basket and then in the 1920s developed into a more ceremonial, and exported item, decorated on the exterior with thayo relief work, often gilded. There is usually a cartouche on the base where the name of the craftsman is given.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A form of Japanese money made of hammered gold. Smaller in size than the oban.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a hair-arranger, fitted into pocket opposite kozuka.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter CARBON (?) and GALENA (?) in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This Japanese term refers to a decorative metal protector which fits onto the bottom of sword sayas, ie. sword sheaths.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This Japanese term refers to a full set of sword mountings. See also the term 'sword'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a small utility knife fitted into the pocket of a sword scabbard.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: End of a backed blade or bladelet deliberately detached by a blow to the backed edge.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a boundary-stone in Ancient Mesopotamia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This Sanskrit term refers to a water vessel (often called a water sprinkler) with a long neck and side spout.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a terminal for a scabbard cord.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Two handled cup with a stemmed base.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a pillow for making lace.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Lacing rings were attached to the bodice of traditional and regional dress in Scandinavia, especially in Sweden, where they were called ‘maljor’, and Norway. They were sewn to the garment in pairs and a ribbon or chain was threaded through them to hold the garment together, with a long thing needle at the end of the ribbon or chain to facilitate the lacing.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Name of a form of money used in Sri Lanka.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a type of transparency, not necessarily photographic, but often so, and can be created using different techniques including painting, printing, or silver gelatin and albumen photographic processes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: When the term refers to part of a helmet, use HELMET.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Burin with one or more spalls that extend along the lateral edge(s) of a flake or blade.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a machine for turning or shaping.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A list of locations with their latitudes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to architecture, not vessels. See the Related Terms for alternatives.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is used for baptism, also enter the term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Greece and Rome this term refers to an object given to brides by their fathers as wedding presents.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a sheet of paper with a printed heading giving address, etc. Term applies to sheets used for tradesmen's bills as well as for writing paper.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Long, stone flake knapped from a Levallois core.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be entered when the object is found in isolation and the object it originated from is unknown. See also 'vessel-cover' and its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Thick tool resembling a slug (hence the name) with retouched on both edges converging at both ends which may be pointed or rounded. The butt is always removed.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to the aniconic form of the god Siva, depicted as a standing phallic column. It is also a Subject term, and should be entered in both fields for sculptures in the shape of a linga. The Associated Name Śiva should also be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a piece from a Chinese board-game.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Logboats are boats made by hollowing out a single log and then shaping the ends and exterior. They can also be modified with the addition of fittings. In Europe, they date from the Mesolithic to the Medieval period and are found throughout northern Europe. It is unlikely that logboats were used at sea or in outer estuaries.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If appropriate, the term MARRIAGE EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Only use this trerm when the pulley has been collected separately from the original loom. The Object Name loom should also be entered for these records. See also the Description of individsual looms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a globular shaped water vessel used throughout India.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Only use this term if the name of the whole object is unknown.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Crescent-moon shaped neck ornament associated early Early Bronze Age

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is only used by the Department of Prehistory and Europe. It does not always refer to a club, and users are advised to search under MACE as well.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to various ground ingredients sealed into envelopes by medicine men in Mexico.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'mahjong-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, a light-hearted Japanese style of sketching evolved called 'manga' which, literally translated, meant 'letting the brush run away with itself'. Such works were generally reproduced in the form of woodblock printed illustrated books. From the early 1900s, this art form developed into a newspaper cartoon or story book with equal pictures and text. Since 1945, manga have expanded to encompass both book and animated film versions, known as 'anime', and have become an international phenomenon. 'Manga' may refer to the original painted or drawn artwork from which the modern printed versions are made. The additional Object Names might include 'illustrated book', 'painting', 'print' and 'drawing'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'manicure-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a specific type of artefact, manufactured from mainly copper alloy in Africa and Europe and exchanged as trade items. Manillas are pennanular-style bracelets or bangles and can be plain or decorated. In some African societies they were worn as personal items of adornment which demonstrated their wearer’s status and wealth.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas: If MATAPE use that term only.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Some of the terrms listed directly under 'Communications Equipment' may be in manuscript ot printed, and should be checked as well as 'manuscript' itself and its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Chest for holding palm leaf mauscripts and writing implements.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Where the term refers to a thumb-piano or a sansa, use SANSA.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This has not been used as a Broad Term. For the tool/implement, use MARKING-TOOL.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to ceramic storage containers usually covered with a brownish glaze. They have been found across broad areas of Asia and the Middle East as they were used along maritime trade routes. The first mention of the name ‘Martaban jar’ is found in an Arab traveller’s writings from 1350, but the jars were probably in use much earlier than this. The name ‘Martaban jar’ probably arose because Martaban was once a major Burmese port for Indian Ocean trade. However, the jars were not necessarily made in the area, and there is evidence that they came from up-country in Burma, as well as Thailand.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should be multiple-keyworded with other terms, such as 'religious/ritual equipment', if appropriate. See also 'burqa'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Costume, or parts of costume, made for or used in masquerades.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Where the object is a CLUB, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a composite of engraved or drawn images on one plane giving a trompe-l'oeil effect. The additional terms PRINT or DRAWING should be added to the Object record as necessary.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a painting or a print for use in an optical viewing device. The terms 'painting' or 'print' are entered as additional Object Names for such records.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In certain contexts, megaphones may be used as musical instruments.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The terms 'drawing' or 'print' should be entered as an additional Object Name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Asia this term refers to ornamentation under sword handle (often incised to improve grip).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to 17thC woodcuts printed to be attached to bales, boxes, etc. For departments other than Prints and Drawings, see the field for Inscription Type.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas this term refers to a message and not a stick for carrying messages.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, enter the additional term MORTAR if the object is made of wood.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a miniature spherical bead commonly used as a trade commodity within the Indian Ocean. The term is only used for records of the Department of Middle East.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a waste flake produced by the notch and snap technique of manufacturing bladelets for use as microliths. Common in Mesolithic and some Upper Palaeolithic assemblages.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a document, made of bronze, recording the discharge of a soldier from the Roman army.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a small inscribed plaque.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to paintings. For Iran (Persia), the term painting is used in preference to minature.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Generally speaking, the category is a catch-all for terms which do not fit under other Top Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has not been used as a Broad Term. Also check the Narrow Terms of WEAPON.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use for coins with manufacturing errors, such as being struck off the flan or double-struck.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term means 'parody picture' in Japanese art. A second Object Name, such as 'print' or 'painting' is also required, as well as the Subject mitate/ yatsushi.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Viking pendant resembling a mitre in shape, and worn in sets on neck-strings to form decorative collars.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term 'model' is entered as well as the Object Name what the model represents (unless it is a Narrow Term of 'model'). The term 'model' is generally used for representations of inanimate subjects (e.g. 'amphora') and thew term 'figure' for animate ones (e.g. 'dancer').

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For individual types of building models, see the Description.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to tableaux, etc. and is mainly used by the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan and the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas. See FIGURE for other departments.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Also check records with Object Name MODEL or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use by the Department of Prints and Drawings from Period VIIIa onwards. Do not confuse with CARTOON. See also the Object Names 'comic book' and 'manga'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a fragment of pottery that has been reused after breakage. Modified potsherds include sherds with their edges ground down to form discs or elongated grinding implements and sherds with linear striations across the surface commonly found in East Africa and referred to as 'bead grinders'. The function of most modified potsherds has not yet been established, particularly the ceramic discs, yet they have a very wide distribution within the Indian Ocean, throughout Iran and into Central Asia. If the function of the modified potsherd is known, an additional Object Name is entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Envelopes, often decorative, created for the specific purpose of making gifts of money to others.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bead of shell which can be strung into shell-bead-money denominations and also into valuable personal ornaments.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Such objects are usually made of stone.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term can be used to refer to any unidentified piece of inscribed stone, etc. Use a more specific Object Name if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Add the additional object name 'sculpture' if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a fastening for a cope.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term MOSAIC should also be entered in the Techniques field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term MOSAIC should also be entered in the Techniques field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term MOSAIC should also be entered in the Techniques field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be used in the sense of 'fitting', and only if the name of the whole object name is not known; otherwise terms such as, e.g. REST or STAND, should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to an object placed over the mouth of a deceased person. If the object is a part, the name of the whole object should be entered instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Three dimensional object produced in a limited edition.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade or flake which has at least two small edges formed by the intersection of two or more burin facets.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Tool with two or more burins on truncations.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan use MUMMY-WRAPPING.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a false head for mummy bundles.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan this term refers to material used as packing during mummification processes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Acient Egypt and Sudan this term refers to the padding used to define shape and features in a mummy. Usually textile.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is used for ballad sheets, sheets of music, produced as individual items or taken from complete music books or albums. Complete music books should have the additional Object Name 'book' if appropriate. Ballad sheets are sometimes referred to as 'broadside ballads'; see also the term 'broadside'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is defined as an instrument with a resonator; for bows to play instruments, the term MUSICAL INSTRUMENT-BOW or a more specific term should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a musical instrument.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a bow used for playing a musical instrument, and should not be confused with MUSICAL BOW which is an instrument.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a miniature musical box in the form of a seal, to be worn on the end of a chatelaine, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Images relating to foreigners in the port of Nagasaki. Enter 'foreigner' as Subject.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Flake tool on which a straight, low-angled 'knife' edge, formed by earlier removals from the dorsal surface, occurs opposite a high-angled, blunt edge formed by an unmodified natural surface.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term INTAGLIO PRINT should be entered in the Technique field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Naucratic figures (Naukratic figures) are small Egyptian limestone, faience or terracotta figurines, representing an Ithyphallic man or child. They often represent Horus as a baby, known as Harpocrates in Greek. Most examples can be dated to the Late Period or early Ptolemaic period. They are particularly common at Naukratis. However, they have been found at other sites in Egypt, and are common in Nile Delta settlements of that period.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A distinctive type of altitude sundial in the shape of a boat.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: "Boat" shaped blade core, common amongst of early Neolithic lithic assemblages from the Levant. They are produced by the working of a single flaking surface from two opposed, obliquely prepared platforms. Often they are on tabular raw material.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a specific garment for people; use TRAPPINGS or its Narrow Terms for animals.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to armour.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In some contexts, the terms head-rest and pillow may have been used..

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the context of the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' South America collections, needle-weights are used with tapestry-needles which may also act as spindles. If the latter, the additional Object Name SPINDLE-WHORL should also be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a specific type of lekythos with a net decoration.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an ephemeral print made for the New Year.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use the term for illustrations in newspapers, magazines, etc. as well as for complete issues.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Burin on a small blade with facets removed from a retouched truncation. The burin facets are often stopped by a small notch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use HANGING-NOOSE or HUNTING-NOOSE if possible.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The rounded front of the scraper is narrower than the width of the flake or blade and projects like a nose. The projection is produced by retouch on one or both sides of the scraper front.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a stone flake with a retouched notch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade which exhibits a retouched notch, or notches.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is restricted to circulating currency on paper.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use a more specific object name if possible.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A particular type of amulet that groups numbers in such a way, that the addition of horizontal, vertical and diagonal lines derive at an identical sum.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is used in the sense of, e.g., 'nut and bolt'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term CULINARY EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional keyword if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A form of Japanese money made of hammered gold.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an object that has been cut off. If the name of the original is known, e.g. bracelet, also enter this term as a second keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also under BASKET for some collections.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object is taken from the drawing.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The terms TOILET/COSMETIC EQUIPMENT or MEDICAL/MEDICINE EQUIPMENT should be entered as additional keywords if appropriate. The constituents, if known, should be entered the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The terms TOILET-EQUIPMENT or MEDICAL/MEDICINE EQUIPMENT should be entered as additional keywords if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Double-key with TOILET-SPOON or MEDICAL/MEDICINE EQUIPMENT if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This refers to a specific type of one-handled cup used in Archaic Greece.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'oracle-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is not a comprehensive category. See also PERSONAL ORNAMENT, and other appropriate categories. In the case of BRAID, the term ORNAMENT should only be used in the absence of a more specific Object Name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a print with decorative ornament for craftsmen in all fields of the applied arts, and is often published in sets. See also 'pattern-book'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A potsherd (or occasionally a piece of limestone) used in the ancient world as a writing surface; in Classical Athens (and perhaps a few other ancient Greek cities), citizens used ostraca to vote on which individuals should be sent into exile, hence English "ostracism."

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is not a Broad Term for all exterior garments, and is used by the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A coin or token created by striking the new design onto an older coin or token, instead of using featureless blanks. Traces of the old design can sometimes be visible though the new one.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Maori name for a paddle is 'hoe'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Korean equivalent of a go-board.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to Chinese dominoes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The names of the constituents should be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In P&D, watercolours, preliminary oil sketches, etc., are considered as drawings; for that department do not use the term painting.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a a collection of texts and/or images to teach and illustrate the art of calligraphy and painting.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional keyword if relevant.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: An addional Object Name should be entered, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term PAN (RITUAL) should be used for the ritual Chinese vessel.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a blank sheet. See also NEWSPAPER, MANUSCRIPT, WRITING-PAPER, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In most contexts, this refers to an image made by cutting out a single sheet of paper or similar material, and usually pasting it to a backing. In Arabic, Persian and Turkish contexts, the term is used for an image created by cutting out several sheets and pasting them to a backing; in other contexts, use collage.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be used when the paper support is the artist's primary form of visual expression. Particularly with the use of dyed paper pulp, and often combined with other techniques such as embossing, burning, tearing or perforating paper. Practised by many artists during the 1970's.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term must also be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a folding and illustrated manuscript, typical of the Burmese court of the 19thC. The Technique 'painted' should be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is specific to Oceanic material, and refers to flexible material securely wrapping an object, not to any type of packaging.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A pareu is a sarong-like wrap used as a garment by men and women in Polynesia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a rawhide container, and an additional Object Name, e.g., BAG, should also be entered if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is used in the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas and does not necessarily refer to a coat, but to a costume.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Burin made on a convex truncation made by abrupt retouch. The burin facet forms an acute angle with this truncation so that the outline shape resembles the beak of a parrot.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, the name of the object used as a passport should also be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the whole object should be entered instead, if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a box for holding decorative patches for the face.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: An insert placed in a shoe to raise the height.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, the term refers to a board recording sequences of warp manipulations.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a book with drawings or prints of different patterns of cloth, wallpaper, ceramic designs, etc. for use by artisans or clients. This term should not be confused with 'ornament print' or 'drawing book'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Coin not produced for general currency, but for internal mint purposes, to demonstrate potential new designs, manufacturing techniques or technical competence.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a large painted cloth used by itinerant bards to narrate epic folk stories.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Refers to the small porcelain tokens issued by Chinese organisations in Thailand in the 19th century. These were initially issued as gambling tokens but were also used more generally as a token currency.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term referes to a Scottish implement used for holding candle-fir.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to ammunition. See also CLAY PELLET.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A circular or annular bracelet with a break in the section. Use for Bronze Age objects only.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan the term PENDANT, rather than its Narrow Terms, should be entered. See also PECTORAL.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a miniature garden.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a knife for cutting pens. See also FOLDING-KNIFE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Point with steep backing retouch forming a convex edge along one side opposite and convergent with, an unmodified edge. The proximal end is also modified. Characteristic of the Late Upper Palaeolithic of northwest Europe.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a quartzite pebble used to strike particular rocks (known as 'rock gongs') in order to produce a melodious sound.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Upper Palaeolithic implement made of antler and perforated with one or more cylindrical holes at the crown end. Often richly decorated these objects were originally called bâton de commandement on the assumption that they were ceremonial staffs. They are now understood to implements used in the manufacture and throwing of spears.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The constituents, if known, should be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This category includes accessories which are worn or carried. See also CARRIER, PERSONAL ORNAMENT and TOILET/COSMETIC EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the collections of the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, see also ORNAMENT as many personal ornaments may have been recorded under this term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal:
A bound book containing a sequence of photographs, by one photographer or several, either with or without accompanying text, often on a particular theme; with particular attention given to its design (binding, jacket, typography, paper, cover); described by Martin Parr and Gerry Badger as "an essay in photographs" ('The Photobook: A History', Phaidon, 2004).
See also 'illustrated book'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers here to a to a montage made from photographic images.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In stone artefact terminology a pick is an artefact which resembles a handaxe but has an elongated pointed form and a thick triangular or quadrangular cross-section. Known from Lower Palaeolithic/Early Stone Age assemblages and, less frequently from later contexts.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'picnic-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term shoudl only be used if the object is not a painting, drawing, or print, or if there is uncertainty.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used if the frame is of significance to the collections.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Coin struck on an unusually thick flan to be several times the normal thickness and weight.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Within stone tool terminology this is a blade, bladelet or flake with a pointed projection formed by retouch. Used for making holes in organic materials such as hides, skins, shell, bone or ivory. The term piercer is translated from the French perçoir and the term awl is sometimes used synonymously.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade or bladelet with steep backing retouch on both edges which converge to form a pointed piercer tip. Used for making holes in organic materials such as hides, shell, bone or ivory.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade, bladelet or flake with a straight, offset or incurved pointed projection formed by bilateral, sometimes alternate, retouch with double or single shoulder.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The constituents, if known, should be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term has been used as a Broad Term for fastening pins. If the object has neen used specifically in the context of dress-making, the term NEEDLEWORK EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a bone point for separating weave.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A plate of pre-drilled measured holes which are equivalent to standard pinion sizes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is restricted to conduits; enter a Narrow Term if more appropriate. See also SMOKING-PIPE, MUSICAL PIPE and URINE-PIPE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to hair; otherwise use ORNAMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, see also records with Object Name BEAD.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a vase moulded in a certain shape, not a vase made of plastic.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term PLASTRON is used in the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas; see also SHIRT-FRONT. If the term refers to armour, use BREAST-PLATE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has been used interchangeably with CHARGER.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See 'card-playing' in the SUBJECT field for designs for playing-cards (Department of Prints and Drawings only).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan plinths often form an integral part of figures or figure-groups and, if subsequently disassociated, have been registered separately.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used if the name of the whole object is unknown.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an item of Maori dance equipment.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: When the point is from a weapon or tool, the name of the object it was part of should be entered instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to an object used for showing the place on a manuscript.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The names of the constituents should be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a block of stone upon which flint or stone tools (such as axes) could be rubbed to produce a polish.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional Object Name if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used if the name of the whole object, such as SWORD or SADDLE, is unknown.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a cheap print, often taking the form of a chap-book, broadside, ballad, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the collections of the Department of Greece and Rome.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the collections of the Department of Greece and Rome.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Rounded sherds cut from vessels that are found across the Middle East and Central Asia from prehistoric times until at least the early medieval period. Uses are not definitely known but suggestions include weights, gaming counters or tokens.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Use for drums made of pottery without membranes; body of drum has hole that creates sound when beaten; used in Africa.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas this term refers to a small bag or container worn by a person.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Records for such objects should include an additional Object Name such as 'painting', 'drawing', 'print', 'rubbing' or 'calligraphy', and the corresponding technique in Techniques.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Term refers to boxed sets and presentation packs of coins.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term covers smoke dried heads, mummified heads, shrunken heads and any other culturally modified and preserved human heads.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to equestrian equipment.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be used to indicate a drawing which was intended for publication either as single sheet print or as a book illustration.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This category applies to the actual printing process, not to the preparation of the matrix.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Prints and Drawings this term includes wood-block, lino-block, metal-plate, litho-stone and screen.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the name of another object, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a public notice.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This includes by-products but is not intended to cover manufacture in general. See also the Top Term TOOL/IMPLEMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has not been used as a Broad Term. See also the Narrow Terms of WEAPON.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the whole object should be entered instead, if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A proof is made as part of the working process. The term is only entered as an Object Name (as well as in the Description) for ceramics, coins or paper money. In the case of pictorial prints (engravings, woodcuts, etc.), the term 'proof' is only entered in the Description field and not repeated as an Object Name..

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to Celtic brooches only.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'punch-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Terms such as TOY, CEREMONIAL EQUIPMENT, etc., should be entered as additional keywords, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is by the Department of the Middle East.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a jar which forms part of a saqia (a waterwheel turned by cattle). The waterwheel has a series of ceramic jars attached to it, each called a qadus. It is these jars which lift the water.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A flat quarter -circular piece of wood or metal with a plumb bob suspended from the apex. The curved edge is usually graduated from 0˚ to 90˚ and is used to measure angles in surveying, gunnery and timekeeping by the Sun and stars.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term relates to an ornamental element in architectural cuspary.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to Inuit clothing, a parka worn by men.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Qur'an boards are used by students to write out extracts from the Qur'an or to practise their writing of particular verses. These are usually washed off after each use - a bit like a slate and chalk. They are generally flat, rectangular and with a handle at one end (or occasionally both).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Qur'an rests are used to support the book and are often folding devices a bit like those used in some libraries to show more precious or fragile books or manuscripts.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A quartz-controlled watch which is automatically adjusted by radio signals transmitted at regular intervals and determined by an atomic clock.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a type of Indian painting which illustrates the different musical modes and links them to emotion and time of day.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is a MUSICAL RASP, that term should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Used during times of food rationing.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to musical instruments.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be used for ukhure.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Name given to figural or ceremonial axe of the Fon peoples, Republic of Benin.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to equipment to wind thread onto a spool.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to clothing, ornaments and other accessories used and/or worn by a ruler and other important functionaries.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Additional Object Names should be entered if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A separate spring-driven device designed to be used in conjunction with an ordinary watch. It is connected either to the canon pinion square or the winding square, the rotation of which indexes the mechanism so that when the repeat function is activated it will repeat the hours and quarters determined by the watch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Name of the original should be entered as an additional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Name of the original should be entered as an additional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Coins (including coin-patterns or coin-proofs), medals or tokens produced after the time of original issue and use, but employing the original dies. They are usually produced as collectors' pieces. Also enter, as an Object Name, the term coin (or coin-pattern or coin-proof), medal or token, for retrieval purposes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT should be entered as an additional keyword if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade which has been modified by retouch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bladelet which has been modified by retouch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Retouched blade with a trapezoidal cross-section detached from a unipolar blade core. Characteristic of the early and middle Bronze Age in the Levant.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Flake which has been modified by retouch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Natural or humanly produced lithic blank with retouch along at least one edge.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The use of the term ridge-pole has been restricted to buildings, and not tents.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an archaeological object, the function of which is uncertain. If part of a FINGER-RING, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term does not refer to an actual flail, and is used for objects in the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a particular rock which was struck by an object known as a 'percussion stone' (e.g. a quartzite pebble) to produce a melodious sound.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has a very specific usage. In the Department of Middle East, the objects are lead strips inscribed in Mandaic language which were then rolled in antiiquity and have since been unrolled for the purpose of reading the inscriptions.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a wheel or cylinder for making patterns.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a specific type of aryballos which is spherical.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the term refers to a SHIELD, that term should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a rubbing-tool; if the object is a GRINDSTONE, that term should be used instead. See also the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is defined as a graduated strip used for measuring length, and should not be confused with RULER.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas this term refers to an object from Papua New Guinea, and appears to be a head-ornament used during the 'Marea' ceremony.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A large flat stone slab worn and dished on the upper surface by its use for grinding grain or pulses to produce flour. A forerunner of the later rotary quern and more modern millstones.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a clay case used for fine ceramics during firing.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the the Object Name 'sake-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to vessels; otherwise FOOD PRODUCT or SAMPLE should be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See the Narrow Terms for specific types of sample, apart from by-products (e.g. SLAG) which are are listed under PRODUCTION/REPLICATION rather than SAMPLE. Specific materials should be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Used by scribes to shake sand on ink, like a blotter.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Sanni masks are Sri Lankan masks used in exorcist rituals (dances) to heal the sick. They represent various diseases and are used by the practitioner to help diagnose which 'illness demon' is making their patient sick.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In Malaysia, the sarong is a length of fabric sewn along narrow ends, forming a tubular garment worn solely on the lower body (see kain panjang for unsewn version). Outside Malaysia, the term 'sarong' has been adapted for a wide variety of uses, especially for fabric lengths wrapped around the waist as a skirt.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is used in preference to 'caricature'. The term 'satire' is also entered as a Subject.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A clock which doubles as a money box. The clock can only be wound up when a coin is dropped into the slot in the top of the case.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a Japanese scabbard. See also shirazaya for plain wooden sleeping scabbards. Either term is entered as an additional Object Name as well as the English nearest equivalent, e.g. 'sword-sheath' and 'saya'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Three sided microlith on which two sides are retouched; edges are of different lengths, whilst the internal angles are also all different from one another.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan this term refers to an object in the form of a beetle, with or without additional decoration. For other forms, e.g. hedgehogs, the term SCARABOID should be entered. The Department of Greece and Rome uses SCARABOID if the object is beetle-shaped, but lacking anatomical detail. For a seal in the form of another animal, e.g. a lion, the term SEAL should be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan the term refers to an object which is not in the form of a beetle, e.g. a hedgehog. See also SCARAB. For the Department of Greece and Rome, the term refers to a beetle-shaped object, lacking anatomical detail. For a seal in the form of another animal, e.g. a lion, use SEAL (or SEAL-MATRIX).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The additional term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be entered if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Multi-image printed sheets intended to be cut out and used for general decorative purposes, as well as for scrapbooks or albums. They first appeared in the 18th-century; by the mid-19th century they were usually produced as chromo-lithographs. They are found in many countries. The German term is Glanzbilder.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The additional terms MODEL, FIGURE, etc. should be entered as appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Records for such objects should include an additional Object Name such as 'painting', 'drawing', 'print', 'rubbing' or 'calligraphy', and the corresponding technique in Techniques.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: As this includes 'figure' a Narrow Term, and 'figure' includes 'doll' and 'puppet' as its Narrow Terms, the search on 'sculpture' as a Broad Term will also retrievesauch objects.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has two very different meanings in the literature. - The most widely used meaning is referred to here, which is an object used to make an impression as a form of signature to secure property or leave a permanent mark on a document. In many cases seals also had amuletic signifiance because of their imagery or the materials from which they were made. - In Roman and Medieval Europe the term seal is used to refer to the wax or metal impression (see seal impression) whereas the object used to make the impression is called a seal-matrix or seal-die as it was usually made in the same manner as a coin-die. See also Object Name intaglio. Dominique Collon (ed.), ''7000 Years of Seals", London: BMP 1997.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a textile purse to hold the Great Seal of England.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The impression of a seal either on a document (either directly in the case of clay tablets or via an originally attached lump of clay, metal or wax sealing in the case of parchments), or soft material such as clay or plaster used to close doors, jars or packaging etc. The term 'seal-impressed' should be entered in Technique.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Term used to describe the material either attached directly to a document (and usually made of clay, wax or metal) or used to close a package, jar or door etc (in which case it may or may not be impressed with a seal). In the Roman period and Medieval Europe, the term refers to items which were for official use by the military or judicial authorities, presumably for sealing bales, boxes, doors, lids, writing tablets and so on. When the sealing is impressed the record should also include a reference to it as a seal impression.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the Department of Greece and Rome.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Metallised security thread used in banknotes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Japanese folding fan.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Asia this term refers to washers used to fill out the space provided for tsuba on a blade.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an Indian stringed musical instrument.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to wraparound shawls worn by both men and women in Ethopia.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an illuminated medallion on the frontispiece of Islamic manuscripts.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A certificate confirming ownership of shares.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term 'sheath' is restricted to the context of arms equipment. See also Narrow Terms 'saya' and 'shirazaya'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the Pacific, and refers to a specific type of object, used as an ornament, valuable, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Money-beads when strung into recognised denominations for exchange purposes

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Disk of white shell pierced to be strung as a personal ornament.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Ring of shell when recognised as a denomination for exchange purposes

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Japanese memorial print commemorating the death of an actor, poet, etc. Enter DEATH in the Subject field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to Japanese plain wooden sleeping scabbards. See also the term 'saya'. Either term is entered as an additional Object Name as well as the English nearest equivalent, e.g. 'sword-sheath' and 'shirazaya'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: When the term refers to armour, use COAT-OF-MAIL.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is used in the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas where it refers to a garment.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when referred to in the documentation, in the absence of a more specific term, and is not a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Shunga ('spring pictures') are explicitly erotic Japanese paintings, prints and book illustrations produced in large quantities, mainly during the Edo period (1600-1868). Most examples are by Ukiyo-e or 'Floating World' school artists such as Utamaro and Hokusai. The additional Object Names 'painting', 'print' or 'illustrated book' should be added as appropriate. The Subject 'eroticism/sex' should also be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is part of a LOOM, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A quadrant which has a grid pattern on the reverse which enables one to determine the sine and cosine of a measured angle.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the context of fishing.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a long-necked Indian lute, and should not be confused with SITER.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a zither-like instrument in a gamelan "orchestra", and should not be confused with SITAR.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Name of the original should be entered as an addtional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to objects resembling banknotes, with a political, satirical or fantasy theme (ie. they are not real money). They are almost always prints, and therefore have the Broad Term 'satirical print', but there are examples which are drawings. The additional Object Names 'drawing' and the Subject 'satire' should be added as appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The additional term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be entered if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a krater in the shape of a skyphos.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A more specific term should be entered instead, if appropriate, such as MONUMENTAL INSCRIPTION, SCULPTURE, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to worked mineral deposits.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A dial clock, designed for wall mounting, with only an indexing device which is electrically activated by a master clock, either at minute or half-minute intervals. The system was commonly used in hospitals, schools and office buildings so that one single master clock in the building would periodically activate all the dials in the building making them all consistently show the same time as that of the main clock. These dials do not work independently of the master-clock system.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should only be used if the sleeve is a discrete object; when part of a GARMENT, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The addtional keyword FUNERARY EQUIPMENT should be entered if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This refers to photographic slides, not microscope slides.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the context of weapons, and if the object was used for hunting, the additional term HUNTING EQUIPMENT should also be entered. If the object is a carrier, the term CARRYING-SLING should be entered instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to the solidified waste product formed at the base of a hearth used during iron smithing.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This category does not include weapons.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a badge of office worn by select members of the court of the paramount chief of Asante (the Asantehene) who are periodically responsible for purifying his soul. Traditionally, most of these personnel were born on the same day of the week as the Asantehene and were therefore believed to share his destiny. They were trusted servants who were employed to deliver messages and were confidants of the king. On the Asantehene’s death they were customarily killed so that they could go on serving their master in the spirit world.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the specific object should be entered as an additional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the specific object should be entered as an additional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: When the object is a bead, use SPACER-BEAD; if it is a GAUGE, use that term or one of its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to architecture.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be entered as a second Object Name for the object it is a specimen of (e.g. banknote or traveller's cheque, etc.). A specimen banknote is a sample note usually distributed to banks, treasuries and law enforcement agencies to familarize them with newly issued currency, and not intended to be used as actual currency.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Long, thin vessel with narrow neck, vertical handle from rim to shoulder and body tapering to small ring base; Late Bronze Age.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: An open bowl of pottery (or rarely of stone), with between two and four internal loops, used in the preparation of thread. The bowl serves both as a container to add moisture to the flax and provide tension, the threads being drawn up through each loop from raw material in the bowl.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A form of Roman copper-alloy token categorised by the erotic nature of their designs. Although they look like small coins and have also been called 'brothel tokens', the variety of numbers carried on similar sized specimens suggests that they were most probably used as gaming pieces. The modern naming of these pieces alludes to the troupe of pornographic entertainers, the Spintriae, reportedly employed by the emperor Tiberius.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the specific object should also be entered if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Spear tip made of bone or antler with a slit cut across the broad base providing a slot into which the top of the spear shaft could be inserted. The size and shape varies from triangular to lozenge forms. Typical of the early Aurignacian period of the Upper Palaeolithic in western Europe and consequently sometimes called an Aurigancian point.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A more specific object name, such as ADZE, should be entered instead, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the whole object should be entered instead, if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to an elongated stone object usually having rounded ends and a ground and polished surface, and known from Bronze Age contexts.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The additional term TEXTILE CRAFTS, or one of its Narrow Terms, should also be entered if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the whole object should be entered instead, if known. See also RAINWATER-SPOUT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a device fastened to the cockpit of the kayak to prevent water from coming into the kayak.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to measuring squares, eg. SET-SQUARE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an impression of an inscription or image, usually in low relief, taken by applying wet paper or other soft material, such as latex. Although sometimes referred to as 'paper moulds', squeezes are distinguished from moulds mainly by the fact that moulds, unlike squeezes, are used to produce other objects, in metal, plaster, etc. See the Object Name 'mould'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term CALCIUM CARBONATE should be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term CALCIUM CARBONATE should be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an object used for stamping a design; see also PUNCH. It should not be confused with POSTAGE-STAMP.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a musical instrument used in the Solomon Islands which consists of a bamboo tube with a hollow end which is stamped on the ground and which resonates. They are often played with flutes, and more recently, with ‘thongafones’.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also Object records with Object Name STAND or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also STENCILLED and STENCIL PRINT in the Techniques Thesaurus.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to one of two photographs of the same object or view taken at slightly different angles, which when viewed together through a stereoscope, create an impression of depth and solidity.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a picture woven in silk, produced using a rare late Victorian technique, covered by Mr Steven's patent.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This ategory includes groups of objects associated with the preparation and consumption of beverages, which loosely may be classified as stimulants, e.g. chocolate, coffee and tea.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has been used to refer to a garment (often a priest's) and not to an accessory. The additional term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should also be entered if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has been used to refer to an accessory, not a waistcoat.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a chisel used for working stone.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: It is assumed that the stopcocks in the collections are for water.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be entered if the name of the whole object is unknown.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas this term refers to a knife used in North America for drawing in the sand or snow to illustrate a story being told.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an implement used for guiding a pen, etc., and should not be confused with RULE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Aurignacian blade with wide notches on opposite edges in the mid-section of the blade.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also Object records with Object Name STRAP or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Add an additional Object Name to specify banner or valance.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a tool, not to a carrier.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Refers to East Asian cash coins strung together as a larger unit of 1000.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term does not refer to musical styli.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of the individual garments making up the suit should also be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an impression taken from a sulphur cast of a niello plate, made in 15thC Italy.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the term refers to an eye-shade, use EYE-SHADE or VISOR.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to privately commissioned prints.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'survey-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the dessert-dish.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a silver coin of James VI of Scotland (before he became James I of England), also known as a ryal, worth 30 shillings Scots, issued 1567-71. The reverse design is a big sword, hence the name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A sling worn over the shoulder or across the body with fastening to carry a sword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to an ornamental receptacle for the pyx.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Group of figures, animals or scene presented on flat base.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is used to cover several types of object, including tablet shaped objects with text or carved images. However, its most important application with across the British Museum collection is in the context of cuneiform tablets, where it refers to a shaped piece of clay (or less commonly, stone) with a cuneiform inscription. Usually rectangular or rounded in shape, and often with a flat obverse and convex reverse.’ Properly differentiated from other cuneiform text vehicles such as prisms, cylinders, dedicatory cones etc. See also 'writing-tablet'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Tablet case refers to the clay envelope used to enclose a clay tablet inscribed with cuneiform. The tablet case will often be inscribed with the same text as the tablet, or an abbreviated version of it, and bear the impression of one or more cylinder or stamp seals.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Ethiopian altar slab made of stone or wood often inscribed with dedications to Christian Saints, Mary and Jesus.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Flat cortical flake with steep retouch around lateral margins. Characteristic of the Chalcolithic/Early Bronze Age in the Levant.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a slung sword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a buttock-ornament. It should not be used for book-illustrations; the term BOOK-ILLUSTRATION should be entered instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used if the name of the whole object is unknown.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the context of the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' South America collections, tapestry needles may either be used for weaving-in weft thread to tapestry, or, apparently, for spinning thread. If the latter, the additional term SPINDLE should also be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a object used for tapping trees, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the name of the whole object, if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'tattooing-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Taukiwauku are general purpose lime spatulas. They are usually a smaller, functional lime spatula, and may have animals, canoes or people carved into the handle. Their availability is not related to a person’s status - anyone can own one.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Such bricks are produced by moulding tea leaf into various forms. In China bricks of tea are prestige items given as valued gifts. They are often decorated with various auspicious symbols. They were also sometimes used as currency.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the the Object Name 'tea-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Neck pendant comprising a shell-disk with a frigate-bird motif overlay of turtle-shell secured by a hole in the centre, as made in Santa Cruz islands

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is part of a LOOM, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is used by the Department of Greece and Rome.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also Object records with Object Name TENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used if the name of the whole object is unknown.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the specific harness should be entered instead, if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Constituent part of a mosaic. The term is also used for Greek and Roman tokens or counters of uncertain function, of various materials. These are under the object name 'token'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The additional term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should also be entered, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is a Top Term encompassing cloths, whether woven or unwoven, but excluding for the most part garment terms (see under COSTUME) and furnishings (see under FURNISHING). It has been used interchangeably with CLOTH in the documentation. See also TEXTILE in the Materials Thesaurus.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a garment in the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Thang-kas are the commonest form of Tibetan painting. Although there are appliqué and embroidered examples, the Broad Term is 'painting' as it applies to the vast majority.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the names of the individual objects forming the costume.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a type of Minoan seal.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the missile context. If the object is a thrower, an alternative Object Name, such as SPEAR-THROWER, should be entered instead. In the collections of the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, these objects may often be models made of glazed composition and used for ceremonial or funerary purposes.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is under HUNTING EQUIPMENT because a large proportion of the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' throwing weapons are used for hunting. It has not been used as a Broad Term for all throwing weapons; see also MISSILE and PROJECTILE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the object used for pulling a bow-string.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: End scraper on a short flake or blade retouch around most of edge to produce a thumbnail shape.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Thunder stones are ancient manmade stone tools, but understood to be or to derive from thunder and used to be kept in rice barns because they were believed to make the rice last much longer i.e. to increase quantity.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to fastenings; see also NECK-TIE.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'tiffin-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a non-striking clock.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should only be used when the name of the whole object is unknown.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a wind chime.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term has been used to refer to a variety of objects, including a cape, gorget, or part of a head-dress.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term TOBACCO-LEAF should be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Asia, the additional term SAGEMONO should also be entered.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'toilet-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term includes objects related to perfume, scents, essences, and those involved in body decoration. Some departments may wish to exclude HANDKERCHIEF from a retrieval under this category.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term GAMING-PIECE should be used for gambling-tokens. Includes Greek and Roman tokens or counters sometimes referred to as tesserae.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the terms PAINTING or SCULPTURE, as appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: See also the Top Term PRODUCTION/REPLICATION.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Term used in the archaeological literature to describe two separate classes of storage jar, one made in the Late Assyrian period in northern Mesopotamia and the other made during the Parthian, Sasanian and Early Islamic periods in Iraq and/or south-west Iran. The latter were typically lined with bitumen and traded by sea along the Persian Gulf and into the Indian Ocean.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with another Object Name, as appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Toy money refers to counters or similar made to look a bit like actual coins. The term 'toy money' is a numismatic category.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term generally refers to a miniature theatre in which the characters are represented by printed pictures mounted on card or wood, popular with children in the 19th century. In some examples, e.g. Mexican toy theatres for the Day of the Dead festival, the figures are made of painted wood, and are moved by a handle.

binding.name: scope
