binding.literal: The term refers to a form of imitation watch usually consisting of a metal disc on which the hours and sometimes minute numerals are embossed. Occasionally there are also hands. Such ‘watches’ are thought to have been used as children’s toys.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, use TAIL-PIECE where more appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This category does not include containers; see also under CONTAINER.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Burin with one or more spalls that extend tranversely across the distal (or more rarely, proximal) end of a flake or blade.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Scraper formed by retouch along the edge opposite, roughly parallel with, the butt. The retouched edge may be straight, convex or concave.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Four sided microliths on which two sides are formed by retouched truncations of the bladelet. There are various forms: isosceles (straight truncations of equal length and the same angle); asymmetrical (straight truncations of different lengths and angles); rectangular (one of the truncated edges perpendicular to the other sides); concave edged (one or both truncations has concave curve); convex edged (one or both truncations convex).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used if the name of the whole object is unknown.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the name of the object if known.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The additional term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should also be entered, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: When the object is a stand, use the term TRIPOD STAND.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a three-legged stand.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The additional term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should also be entered, if appropriate. See also TRIPTYCH PRINT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the names of the individual objects comprising the trousseau.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade which displays more or less abrupt marginal retouch along all or part of one edge above the butt and is truncated at one or both ends by abrupt retouch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bladelet which displays more or less abrupt marginal retouch along all or part of one edge above the butt and is truncated at one or both ends by abrupt retouch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Blade with abrupt retouch at one end at right angles to the axis of percussion.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Bladelet truncated at one or both ends by abrupt retouch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Flake which displays abrupt retouch at the proximal and/or distal end, which has subsequently been used as a platform(s) for the removal of flakes from the dorsal and/or ventral surface. In Middle Eastern contexts these are often referred to as Nahr Ibrahim truncations.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A truncation is formed by continuous abrupt retouch which forms distinct angles with the edges of a blade, bladelet or, rarely, a flake. The truncation may remove the proximal end of a blade and be described as proximal or the distal end to be distal. Truncated edges may be straight, oblique, convex or concave.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Small clay votive image of a stupa, pressed from a metal mould. Used in Tibet and placed in shrines. The lineal descendents of the clay stupas found at early Buddhist sites in India, such as Bodh Gaya (examples from BG in BM collection, from Cunningham).

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Tibetan word for small, usually rectangular paintings on cloth or on stiff paper that are used in Buddhist ritual. Sometimes they are strung together.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term refers to a guard between the blade and the hilt of Japanese swords and other bladed weapons.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to the hilt of any Japanese blade and is entered as an Object Name whether part of a complete assembly or found in isolation. See also 'fuchi-kashira' and 'menuki'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a carrying strap that sits across the forehead to help distribute the weight of a object carried on the back.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is a flat metal anthromorphic votive figure made by the Muisca culture.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a hook upon which turbans are hung.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object has been used in a toilet or cosmetic context, the additional term TOILET/COSMETIC EQUIPMENT should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a perspective picture particularly relating to townscapes or building interiors. The term should be entered both as an Object Name and in the Subject field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas the term should only be used for the North America collections; for the Oceania collections the term MAIKA-PIECE should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to clothes worn under others, especially next to the skin.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Stone projectile tip modified on one face. These usually have a willow leaf form with straight-slightly convex parallel sides with a rounded butt and pointed tip. These points vary in size and could have been used to tip arrows, darts, spears or lances. They are found in the European Upper Palaeolithic and the Neolithic of Africa and Europe.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the names of the individual objects comprising the uniform.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should only be used when the documentation does not provide sufficient information to enter an object name.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to vessels.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Figure of bullfinch sold in some shrines in Japan, kept in homes to absorb lies throughout the year and exchanged for a new bird the following year.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The name of the whole object should be entered instead, if known. If the object is a float-valve, use the term FLOAT-PLUG.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The names of the constituents should be entered in the Materials field.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with Object Name VEHICLE or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers here to a piece of cloth,, plain or decorated, worn by women and girls over the head or face, either as part of a hat or head-dress or in order to conceal or protect the face.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This has been used interchangeably with LID. It is also used for complete covers, e.g. of basketry, for vessels.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with the Object Name VESSEL or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term WAISTCOAT should be used if more appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the ecclesiastical context.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Only to be used for prints of designs appearing on banknotes when they are not part of a printed note or a proof Term is not used by Prints & Drawings.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is from a HELMET, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This category is intended to encompass mainly two-dimensional objects with images. See also 'communications equipment'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with other Object Names, as appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with Object Name WAGON or its Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term has not been used as a Broad Term for garments worn around the waist.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is a tent-wall, the term TENT should be used instead.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term is used to describe stone or (more commonly) purposefully fired clay cones which were applied as architectural decoration in shrines in Mesopotamia during the second half of the fourth millennium BC. In some cases there is evidence for the flat ends of the cones being painted so that the final compositions had a geometric appearance, perhaps inspired by woven matting. The technique also spread to south-west Iran and the Egyptian delta at the same period. P.R.S. Moorey, 'Ancient Mesopotamian Materials and Industries. The Archaeological Evidence', Oxford: Clarendon Press (1994), pp. 309-310.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This has not been used as a Broad Term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas this term refers to a North American bag-like container attached to a wall.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Records for such objects should include an additional Object Name such as 'painting', 'drawing', 'print', 'rubbing' or 'calligraphy', and the corresponding technique in Techniques.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the name of the object.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term watch-fob refers to a small medallion or ornament which is attached by a short chain or ribbon to a fob-watch.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The additional Object Names 'print', 'drawing', etc. should be added as appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A form of clock which is used to automatically record the presence of a watchman at a particular location at allotted times. The clock is locked to the watchman but is inspected by a supervisor to check that the watchman was on duty.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to, for example, an Egyptian "shaduf" and Archimedean screw. If used for irrigation, double-key with IRRIGATION EQUIPMENT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Water-pipes were invented at the beginning of the seventeenth century, either in Iran or India. They are known in Persian as qalyun or qalyan, India as a huqqa or hookah and Arabic as narghileh or shisha; they are also popularly also known as a hubble-bubble pipe.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This term should not be confused with BAILER.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Asia see also RELIGIOUS/RITUAL VESSEL.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: An object employed in meteorological predictions.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: This is not an invitation, but a card to commemorate the event

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Prehistory and Europe, see also POSY-RING.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: It is assumed that the term refers to measuring-weights. For objects used for 'weighing-down' see the Related Terms of WEIGHT.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'weiqi-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A more specific term should be used if possible.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The main use of this object is as a spear or dart-thrower. When the object has been used in the context of games, the term GAME should be entered as an additional keyword.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Enter a second Object Name, as necssary, for the specific vessel, e.g. vase.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a diagram, similar to a compass-rose, except that it indicates the directions (or names) of the winds. There is often (but not always) a detachable wind-vane that can be put in the centre of the wind-rose. An additional Object Name should be entered, such as 'drawing' or 'print', as appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term should only be used if the object is complete; otherwise enter one of the Narrow Terms.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Asia's Chinese collections, see also RELIGIOUS/RITUAL VESSEL.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: A plate with graded cut-outs around the edge, used for measuring the gauge of wire.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a 7lb weight used for weighing bales of wool.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the context of hunting.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The additional term DECORATED PAPER should also be entered, if appropriate.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term FUNERARY WREATH should be entered instead, if more appropriate. Where the term refers to head-gear use HEAD-BAND, etc.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a sheet with a pictorial or ornamental border designed for a child to provide a specimen of handwriting. Such sheets are sometimes referred to as Christmas sheets.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term covers different types of object. One type consists of a wooden board written on in ink, e.g. from Africa. The second type consists of wooden or ivory boards with wax-filled recesses, sometimes hinged together and the ancient Middle Eastern examples represent the beginning of the tradition continued in Egypt and in the Romano-British context, where they are referred to as writing-tablets; see under 'writing-tablet'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a handbook of calligraphy.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'writing-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: These objects have also been referred to as 'writing-boards' in the literature. See also the term 'tablet'. The term 'writing-tablet' is used for tablets with inscriptions, usually made of wood but also sometimes of other materials such as copper alloy, ivory, etc. Where they contain multiple pages, they may be hinged. There are two varieties: 1) stilus-tablets, on which the writing was incised with a pointed stilus into a layer of wax recessed into the wooden tablet. 2) leaf-tablets, which were thin slices of wood inscribed in ink with a pen. The so-called ‘Vindolanda Tablets’ are in fact writing-tablets.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' Oceania collections, this term refers to an ornamental stick used in ceremonies.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a Chinese container for shaking dice.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term applies to yokes used by people, rather than animals, as load-carriers. See also yoke (harness) and other yoke entries.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: If the object is a LOAD-CARRIER, use that term.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: Images relating to foreigners in the port of Yokohama around 1860; or imagery of foreign countries produced around this time in Japan. Enter 'foreigner' as Subject.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: For the Department of Asia this term refers to an Indian object representing the female generative organ, and often combined with the linga. See also LINGA.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'yut-set'.

binding.name: scope
binding.literal: The term refers to a painted ceramic disc, like a pot-lid, used as an icon of the god.
